children.value: f(x) = 3 * cospi(2x) - cispi(x)    # cispi(x) := exp(1im * π * x)
, we set up nodes in the interval

children.html: [0,2)[0,2)[0,2)

children.value: and then examine the resulting coefficients.

using FFTW
c = fft(y) / N
freq = [0:n; -n:-1]
@pt :header=["k", "coefficient"] [freq round.(c, sigdigits=5)]

children.value: Fourier’s greatest contribution to mathematics was to point out that
periodic function is just a combination of frequencies—infinitely many of them in general, but truncated for computational use. Here we look at the magnitudes of the coefficients for

children.html: f(x)=exp⁡(sin⁡(πx))f(x) = \exp( \sin(\pi x) )f(x)=exp(sin(πx))

children.value:
f(x) = exp( sin(pi*x) )     # content at all frequencies
n = 9;  N = 2n+1;
t = [ 2j / N for j in 0:N-1 ]      # nodes in [0,2)
c = fft(f.(t)) / N

freq = [0:n; -n:-1]
scatter(freq, abs.(c);
    xaxis=(L"k", [-n, n]),  yaxis=(L"|c_k|", :log10), 
    title="Fourier coefficients",  legend=:none)
The Fourier coefficients of smooth functions decay exponentially in magnitude as a function of the frequency. This decay rate is determines the convergence of the interpolation error.
